nodes.title: Set your pose count puller here
Mode Switching
widgets_values: Most switches I try to use fail for one reason or another.  Until we have a good set of switch nodes the community can use, this is what we're stuck with.  Just connect the appropriate input node to the Poses node on the right, below this.

nodes.title: About Using ControlNET
widgets_values: You can toggle ControlNet On/Off with the switch below.  If you turn it off you will have complete control via the prompts.  If on, then The Machine will use the part of ControlNet you enable as well as the prompts.  I typically only use Pose, but sometimes Canny does great things with hair.

Pick a good clear headshot of your model.  You just need one.  The sharper/clearer though, the better your results will be. Don't overwhelm The Machine with too large of a file size though.  1024 on the longest side is what I use.  All things in balance.

nodes.title: Touch-up notes
widgets_values:
While this may look and generally act like my Makeup Counter Workflow, it's being used here a bit differently.  This one can use a different sampler during a production run for slightly different effects. 

I'm running this more for some extra detail on the eyes and face rather than applying a full set of makeup.

Also, ONLY the face prompts go through this, not the full prompt/pose.  It seems to give better effect in this use case.

Adjust Makeup Layers as needed, but I've not needed to touch that number yet.

nodes.title: Be a hero!
widgets_values: If you are a node maker, we need some good all purpose on/off and three way logic switches that are intuitive to use and that will pass any pipe either direction.  Ask me for a design spec.  Be a community hero.

nodes.title: Batch Notes
widgets_values: If you aren't running a batch of images you'll need to select each of these nodes and hit control-b to turn them off.  Otherwise you could get stuck in a batch process from the pits of hell.

nodes.title: Batch Notes
widgets_values:
Change this to the directory where you put your posing pictures.  The Machine will look at the picture and extract the pose.

Change the job counter to match the number of poses you have.

nodes.title: Rendering Notes
widgets_values: Yes, we do a lot of rendering here because we want results we can be proud of.  So we do a first pass, touch up the face, then do a second pass.  After that we switch to the SDXL Turbo model to do a 4x Upscale.  This will add detail which will still be present when we take that image and downscale it to 2x size.  Both 4x and 2x are saved as Print_ and Web_ respectively in dated subdirectories.  (I use a date format that sorts in date order oldest to newest.)

Release Notes:

v. 1.0 - December 8, 2023
  -Initial release
v. 1.1 - December 8, 2023
  -Tweaked a few settings that were having a strange effect.
v. 1.11 - December 10
 -Discovered and fixed the error caused the the incorrect string node for automation.
 -Last update before version 2.0 released

nodes.title: About
widgets_values:
This just kind of evolved one day out of two other projects.  The idea is to be able to plan a complete photo shoot and let The Machine do it by pulling poses out of a folder and shooting your model. 

You can set up whole photoshoots at any location you can imagine, and many you can't.

The prompt is set up so there are lots of things to choose from if you are drawing a blank.

Just describe your model's clothing, set up the other style prompts and set The Machine to taking pictures.

Facial Expressions tend not to change.  I'll have to work on that.  But hey, you can be the editor of your own fashion magazine, or cosplay publication, or what ever you might choose.

Just is just the first version, too.  I've got some interesting ideas to explore around this.  Stay tuned.

Oh, if you like it, consider buying me a coffee to show your appreciation.

Have fun!

Clark Glenn Davis, aka Verevolf
